title: She Sleeps Like a Rock, On a Jade Pillow

body: 450 Billion Oreos to Go Q. Why is 15th Street at Ninth Avenue now called Oreo Way? A. Because that is the birthplace of America's favorite cookie. In 1898 several baking companies merged to form the National Biscuit Company, Nabisco, and opened a large industrial bakery on Ninth Avenue between 15th and 16th Streets at the Chelsea Market Building.
title: F.Y.I.

body: FROM time to time, Duke Snider returns to Brooklyn. title: Sports of The Times; Brooklyn Royalty Comes Home Again

body: The City Council voted overwhelmingly yesterday to revise the term-limits law, eliminating a provision that held some council members to a maximum of only six years in office, rather than eight. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is likely to veto the measure, his aides said yesterday, although few expect him to use his pulpit to rail against the change. A
title: City Council Passes Measure On Term-Limits Disparity

body: In Spain and Italy, ''logs'' of pressed figs and walnuts are sliced and served with cheese. title: FOOD STUFF; Bread That Includes the Major Food Groups: Walnuts, Wheat and Figs

author: Michael Shapiro's next book, ''The Last Good Season: Brooklyn, the Dodgers and Their Final Pennant Race Together,'' is due out next year.
body: I was 4 years old when the Dodgers left Brooklyn, but unlike the team, I stayed. I never went to Ebbets Field. I never even saw it. title: MY BROOKLYN; The Team That's Filling the Void the Dodgers Left Behind

title: Brooklyn Gets a Zagat Guide to Call Its Very Own

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer Charged In Deadly Crash

title: No Particular Place to Go

body: If it were a dog's world, Cassius Marcellus Coolidge would be more famous than he is, which is pretty much not at all. title: Artist's Fame Is Fleeting, But Dog Poker Is Forever

title: The Brooklyn Guy and the Movie Guy: It's a Mobster Scenario

body: St. Cecilia Roman Catholic Church, housed in a 19th-century building in East Harlem, has run out of space. Not for parishioners, but for their icons. It all started in the mid-1990's, when Mexican parishioners staked out a corner for a shrine to their patron saint, the Virgin of Guadalupe. Soon, black parishioners took another corner of the church
title: In Many Churches, Icons Compete for Space; Multiple Shrines to Patron Saints Testify to a Rivalry of the Devout

body: From Bay Ridge in Brooklyn to Deer Park on Long Island, the marching bands and the tunes they played were all familiar: ''You're a Grand Old Flag,'' ''Over There'' and ''God Bless America.'' body: Maestro's Farewell In 1992 after Kurt Masur became the music director of the New York Philharmonic, he began what is now a tradition: a free Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. body: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday that he would try to bolster the management of nine struggling New York City school districts by requiring five successful districts to show them how to do everything from balancing the books to training teachers and principals. Mr. Levy said he would pay the five consulting school districts $250,000
title: Levy Orders 5 Strong Districts To Help 9 That Are Struggling

body: I FIRST came to New York City when I was a child, 9 or 10, on a morning train from Boston, with my great-aunts Ruth and Grace. It was just before Christmas and snowing a little. title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW; On the Sidewalks of New York

body: Alan Dale, the Brooklyn-born baritone who crooned his way to popularity in the late 1940's and the 1950's with hits like ''Oh, Marie'' and ''Cherry Pink (and Apple Blossom White),'' died on Saturday at a hospital in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. title: Alan Dale, 73, a Crooner Popular in the 40's and 50's

title: Paid Notice: Deaths KOSTER, REV. RAYMOND

body: THIS is what it was like when the Islanders ruled the springtime. title: Sports of The Times; For One Game, the Good Old Days Come Back for the Islanders

body: New Yorkers' favorite sounds? Judging from the response to our invitation last Sunday to name a memorable sound of the city, the clip-clop of horses' hooves ranked high, especially police horses, especially on cobblestones. Also much loved were the sounds of birds: red-tailed hawks on Fifth Avenue, finches on the West Side, sea gulls in Manhattan
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK VOICES; Finding the City's Sweet Music In Hoofbeats, Coffee Carts and Pining Bells

body: Kevin Graham sat in his living room and began to cry. title: LACROSSE; Prep School Game Introduces Motivation Skills to Inner City Children

Instead, Ms. Simeone felt enlightened, humbled and awed by
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: ANTITERRORISM TRAINING; Two Days of Learning What to Do, and What Not to Do

body: ANY vehicle that calls itself a family car should have a back seat big enough to divide into kingdoms. title: ONLINE SHOPPER; Why Kick the Tires? Just Click the Mouse

body: Detectives searched the home, business and car of a Brooklyn man whose lower right leg was blown off by a pipe bomb explosion on Sunday, seizing wire, metal connectors and business records yesterday, law enforcement officials said. The blast beside a minivan rented by the man and parked outside his Borough Park home initially sent a frisson of fear
title: Police Search Home and Business of Brooklyn Man Hurt in Pipe Bomb Blast

body: BRIGGS-James G. Of 10th Street, died Friday, March 22, 2002, at the Brooklyn VA Hospital in Bay Ridge. He was 79. Mr. Briggs was a Sergeant First Class in the United States Army serving from 1941 to 1961 in the Philippines, Korea, Germany and
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BRIGGS, JAMES G.

body: A pipe bomb in an orange bag exploded beside a minivan parked in one of Brooklyn's busiest Jewish neighborhoods yesterday morning, critically injuring a Hasidic man and briefly sending shudders of fear through a community anticipating Passover and concerned over mounting violence in the Middle East. Investigators said the bomb, with an ignition
title: Pipe Bomb Badly Injures Brooklyn Man

body: ON a winter afternoon, the light in Snooky's Pub in Park Slope, Brooklyn, is almost the color of Scotch and water. Outside, the baby stroller army rolls down Seventh Avenue. Inside there is cigarette smoke, a Dennis Quaid movie playing silently on TV, and murmured talk and laughter around the polished bar, the light glinting on the upside-down
title: The Day the Boy Fell From the Sky

body: A Bay Ridge lawyer was arrested yesterday on charges that he swindled 10 of his clients, many of them elderly, out of $2 million, said Charles J. Hynes, left, the Brooklyn district attorney. In one case, the lawyer, Frank Gangemi, 38, is accused of stealing more than $600,000 from a 90-year-old man by cashing in the man's life insurance policies,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest In Swindle Case

It was the start of a free service financed by the Federal Emergency
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE; One Happy Result of 9/11: Free Ferry Will Stay Afloat

title: Bloomberg Says Teacher Pact Isn't Tied to Mayoral Control

body: In less than two hours, criminals robbed or tried to rob four banks yesterday morning in Brooklyn and Queens. Last year, roughly one bank in New York City was robbed each business day, according to the F.B.I. So far, the police do not see any links between any of yesterday's robberies. More than $6,000 in all was taken, said Jerry Varson, a Police
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Robbers Strike Four Banks

title: Gucci Bags, Satin Blouses and Joy; Century 21, a Downtown Fixture, Reopens to Cheers

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Official Cleared In Fight with Teacher

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: A SUSPICIOUS DEATH; Memphis Fraud Case Is Long on Clues but Short on Answers

title: In Albany, a Redistricting Plan to Help the Majority Party

title: Attention, Downtown Shoppers

title: Running in Place

title: Redistricting: Add a Seat, Gain an Edge

title: Teacher and Administrator Are Arrested in Fight at School

body: My old sauntering buddy Danny got an offer he couldn't refuse, if he had been given the chance. A friend asked Danny's wife, Annie, if he'd like to walk across India with him. title: A Brief Walk Through Time
